magnitudeAbsoluteV.note: Error does not include uncertainty in distance

commentsKinematics.value: HI line widths available in Koribalski et al. (2004)
HI line widths available in Karachentsev et al. (2001a)
Stellar velocity gradient constrained to <5 km s-1 at 90% confidence
Stellar velocities based on carbon stars; HI boundaries between LMC, SMC, bridge, and interface regions not clearly defined
Castro et al. (2008) obtain stellar velocities for ~200 massive blue stars and find that their kinematics closely trace the HI rotation curve
Stellar velocity dispersion rises rapidly toward center and presents strong evidence for a supermassive black hole (e.g., see also van der Marel et al. 1997)

commentsMetallicity.value: Likely significant age spread and gradients?

commentsGeneral.value: Distance based quantities are the mean of those derived assuming the 'Hubble flow' and 'Nearby' methods.

commentsKinematics.value: HI line widths available in Koribalski et al. (2004)
HI line widths available in Begum et al. (2008b) and Huchtmeier et al. (2003)

commentsGeneral.value: Loose NGC 3109 subgroup. Interacting with Antlia?

commentsKinematics.value: Stellar velocity dispersion based on four stars
See also Huchtmeier & Richter (1986); HI line widths available in Longmore et al. (1982) and Huchtmeier & Richter (1986)
Velocity difference of 8.4 ± 1.4 km s-1 between stars in the east and west
Stellar velocity dispersion corresponds to dominant component, and there is evidence for a hotter component with velocity dispersion ~ 9 km s-1

commentsMetallicity.value: HRS of a single star in Simon et al. (2010)

commentsGeneral.value: Loose NGC 3109 subgroup. Interacting with NGC 3109?

commentsKinematics.value: HI rotational velocity measured at r = 1.5 arcmin

publication.value: A. G. Wilson. Reported in Holmberg (1958)

commentsMetallicity.value: Derived in E. Skillman et al., (2012 in preparation)

commentsKinematics.value: HI velocity dispersion shows significant spatial variation
Stellar kinematics derived using 10 young B supergiants + HIi regions; HI gradient of ~1.3 km s-1 arcmin-1
HI measurements complex due to location!
Demers et al. (2006) obtain velocities for >100 AGB stars.

commentsGeneral.value: Zone of obscuration. Binary with B?

commentsKinematics.value: HI cloud offset from optical center of Phoenix, proposed as supernova-driven outflow; HI velocity gradient of ~10 km s-1 observed over ~8 arcmin
HI rotational velocity measured at r = 2 arcmin; see also Huchtmeier et al. (2003), Begum et al. (2008b), and Swaters et al. (2009)

commentsGeneral.value: Member of the Canes Venatici I cloud

commentsKinematics.value: HI velocity gradient of ~3.3 km s-1 arcmin-1
See also Begum et al. (2008b)
Stellar velocity gradient of 5.5 ± 0.5 km s-1 deg-1
Stellar velocity gradient of ~16 km s-1 over ~2 × rh; unlikely associated with nearby HI cloud
HI line widths available in Koribalski et al. (2004)
HI velocity gradient of ~42 km s-1 measured over ~3 arcmin
Stellar velocity dispersion based on three stars

commentsGeneral.value: Zone of obscuration. Binary with A?

commentsKinematics.value: HI velocity gradient of ~2.5 km s-1 arcmin-1
HI structure consists of a rotating disk and a kinematically distinct, elongated "spur"
Stellar velocity gradient of 2.5 ± 0.8 km s-1 deg-1
Not associated with HI detection in Blitz & Robishaw (2000)

commentsGeneral.value: Gibson Reaves gave this galaxy his initials

commentsKinematics.value: Lumpy HI velocity distribution, with some evidence of an overall velocity gradient
Stellar velocity gradient of 6.3 ± 0.2 km s-1 deg-1
HI line widths available in Huchtmeier & Richter (1986)

commentsGeneral.value: Distance based quantities are the mean of those derived assuming the 'Hubble flow' and 'Nearby' methods.

commentsKinematics.value: HI line widths available in Begum et al. (2008b)
Tentative stellar velocity gradient across minor axis of 7.7 ± 1.2 km s-1; unassociated with nearby HI cloud
Stellar velocity gradient of 5.5 ± 1.2 km s-1 deg-1

radiusHalfLight.note: Value is approximate as the PDF for this quantity is complex.

commentsKinematics.value: Gaseous disk embedded in complex, extended HI distribution, (with a dispersion of around 30±40 km s-1)
Stellar velocities based on red giant branch stars; stellar velocity gradient of 8.3 km s-1 deg-1; HI boundaries between LMC, SMC, bridge, and interface regions not clearly defined
See Huchtmeier et al. (2000) for attempted HI observations
HI velocity gradient of 6 km s-1 arcmin-1.

commentsMetallicity.value: Assumes an age of 4 Gyr; for an ancient population, find [Fe/H] -1.9

properties.name: extinction
properties.description: Foreground reddening, E(B-V), measured directly from the Schlegel et al 1998 maps (they do not include the recalibration by Schlafly & Finbiener 2011)

properties.name: magnitudeApparentV
properties.description: Apparent V magnitude in Vega mags

properties.name: massDynamicalHalfLightRadius
properties.description: Dyanmical mass within the half-light radius.

properties.name: massNeutralHydrogen
properties.description: Mass of neutral hydrogen gas (calculated for the adopted distance modulus), M_HI (10^6M_sun)

properties.name: massStellar
properties.description: Stellar mass assuming a V-band stellar mass-to-light ratio of 1 in Solar units.

properties.name: membership
properties.description: Group membership (G=Milky Way; A=M31; L=Local Group; N=Nearby).

properties.name: metallicityMeasurementTechnique
properties.description: Technique used to measure metallicity: 1=High resolution spectroscopy; 2=Spectral synthesis; 3=CaT calibration; 4=CMD modelling; 5=Isochrones; 6=color of red giant branch

properties.name: positionAngle
properties.description: Position Angle of major axis in degrees measured east from north

properties.name: radiusHalfLightAngular
properties.description: Half-light radius measured on major axis, rh(arcmins)

properties.name: radiusExponentialScaleLengthV
properties.description: Radial exponential scale length in V-band, reV(arcmins)

properties.name: radiusExponentialScaleLengthI
properties.description: Radial exponential scale length in I-band, reI(arcmins)

properties.name: surfaceBrightnessEffectiveV
properties.description: Mean surface brightness within the half-light radius.

properties.name: velocityAzimuthalMilkyWay
properties.description: Azimuthal velocity relative to Milky Way center.

properties.name: velocityLocalGroup
properties.description: Velocity relative to Local Group center.

properties.name: velocityMilkyWay
properties.description: Velocity relative to Milky Way center.

properties.name: velocityRadialMilkyWay
properties.description: Radial velocity relative to Milky Way center.

properties.name: velocityVerticalMilkyWay
properties.description: Vertical velocity relative to Milky Way center.
